section.title: First conditional + if/when/unless/as soon as
section.sectiontitle: Use the First Conditional to talk about real possibilities in the future. Make the First Conditional with if + Present Simple + will (or won't).
section.text1: I want to pass my exam.
section.text1a: If I work hard, I will pass my exam.
section.text2: I want to feel good tomorrow.
section.text2a: If I go to bed late, I won't feel good tomorrow.
section.sectiontitle2: We can also use if + Present Simple + should/may/can.
section.text3: You want to arrive at the airport at seven o'clock.
section.text3a: If you leave at six, you should arrive at seven.
section.text4: You want to get a cheap ticket.
section.text4a: If you buy a ticket on the Internet, you can get it cheap.

section.title: First conditional + if/when/unless/as soon as
section.text1: If I don't get up early, I'll miss the bus.
section.text1a: Unless I get up early, I'll miss the bus.
section.text2: They will get burned if they don't use sun cream.
section.text2a: They will get burned unless they use sun cream.
section.sectiontitle2: We often use when instead of if. It means the situation is 100% certain. As soon as means immediately.
section.text3a: When I wake up tomorrow, I'll have a shower.
section.text4a: I'll call you as soon as my plane lands.
